problemStatement.formal: ∀ n : ℕ, ∃ p : ℕ, Nat.Prime p ∧ p > n ∧ p % 4 = 1
problemStatement.plain: There are infinitely many primes congruent to 1 modulo 4.
whyMatters: Special case of Dirichlet's theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions
Demonstrates the distribution of primes across residue classes
Uses Fermat's two squares connection: p | k² + 1 implies p ≡ 1 mod 4

proven: infinitely_many_primes_1_mod_4: ∀ n : ℕ, ∃ p : ℕ, Nat.Prime p ∧ p > n ∧ p % 4 = 1
primes_1_mod_4_infinite: Set.Infinite {p : ℕ | Nat.Prime p ∧ p % 4 = 1}
no_largest_prime_1_mod_4: ¬∃ p, Nat.Prime p ∧ p % 4 = 1 ∧ ∀ q, Nat.Prime q → q % 4 = 1 → q ≤ p

knowledge.progressSummary: COMPLETE: Elementary proof in InfinitudePrimes4k1.lean using N = (2·(n+1)!)² + 1 construction. Uses Mathlib's SumTwoSquares infrastructure.
builtItems: InfinitudePrimes4k1.prime_dvd_sq_add_one_mod_four - key lemma: odd p | k² + 1 implies p ≡ 1 mod 4
InfinitudePrimes4k1.exists_odd_prime_factor - odd numbers > 1 have odd prime factors
insights: Key insight: if odd prime p | k² + 1, then -1 is QR mod p, so p ≡ 1 mod 4
Every odd prime factor of N is ≡ 1 mod 4
At least one prime factor p > n since p ∤ (n+1)!
No Dirichlet or analytic NT needed - completely elementary
